core_components: Linear Algebra and Complex Vector Spaces

practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: I need to establish a solid grasp of state vectors and basic gates before I try to understand entanglement or algorithms, otherwise the notation will become a barrier.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Solving linear algebra problems involving Bra-Ket notation and matrix-vector multiplication.
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Simulating single-qubit gates on a Bloch sphere visualization tool.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Performing standard matrix multiplication and identifying identity gates.
difficulty_profile.challenging: Mapping physical rotations to unitary matrices and understanding phase shifts.

objective: Can manually calculate the state vector after a sequence of 3 gates.
Can define the 4 postulates of quantum mechanics without reference.
subjective: Feeling less intimidated by the notation in research papers.
Visualizing state changes on the Bloch sphere feels intuitive.

practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: Moving from one to multiple qubits is where quantum computing gets its power; I need to focus on the CNOT gate and Bell states to understand how qubits interact.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Constructing and decomposing 2-qubit and 3-qubit circuits in Qiskit.
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Calculating tensor products of state vectors manually to verify simulation results.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Building a basic Bell state circuit.
difficulty_profile.challenging: Tracing the state of a 3-qubit system through a circuit involving controlled-Z or Toffoli gates.

objective: Successful implementation of a Quantum Teleportation circuit.
Zero errors in calculating the output of a 2-qubit system manually.
subjective: Grasping the concept of non-separability in entangled states.
Confidence in using Kronecker products for system expansion.

practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: To reach the intermediate level, I have to stop just following tutorials and start building oracles and implementing algorithms like Grover's from scratch.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Coding the Deutsch-Jozsa and Grover algorithms for specific search problems.
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Analyzing the gate depth and complexity of implemented circuits.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Copying an algorithm template from documentation.
difficulty_profile.challenging: Designing a custom phase oracle for a specific logic function.

objective: Correct output from a 4-qubit Grover search on a simulator.
Implementation of a Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) for a simple molecule.
subjective: Ability to explain how constructive interference leads to the correct answer.
Deciphering circuit diagrams in intermediate-level textbooks.

objective: Accuracy rate of manual state vector calculations.
Successful completion of Qiskit or IBM Quantum challenges.
Reduction in time taken to implement a standard algorithm from scratch.
subjective: Self-rated clarity of the 'Quantum Speedup' concept.
Ease of translating a mathematical description of a gate into a code implementation.

architect_notes: I should focus on the 'why' behind the math early on to avoid burnout when things get abstract.
Since I only have 6 hours a week, I will split them into three 2-hour blocks to maintain focus on the heavy mathematical concepts.
I'll use simulators heavily before trying to run on real hardware to avoid the frustration of noise and queue times.
The transition from 1-qubit to 2-qubits is a common sticking point; I'll give myself permission to repeat Cycle 2 if needed.

details.reason: User initiated a new learning session.

timeline.title: Initial Practice Strategy Created
timeline.summary: Initial practice strategy created for ['Learn Capacitor for React TS for App Development'].
